summary: The U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania yesterday entered a final judgment against Johnnie X. Stroud, a Pennsylvania parole violator who was previously sentenced to a prison term of 41/212 to 15 years.  According to the court's order, Stroud consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from violating Section 6138(a)(5) of the Parole Code and orders him to serve the remainder of his original sentence.  The court also ordered Stroud to pay a $75,000 civil penalty.  In a parallel action, the Pennsylvania Board of Probation and Parole issued a no-merit letter to Stroud on February 23, 2012, stating that the Board had the ability to obtain him from federal custody to serve his state sentence, without credit for any periods of time he was incarcerated while on parole.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the Board's No-Merit Letter, the Board agreed that Stroud violated the pre-sentence confinement provision of the federal parole laws, and that he was entitled to credit for the time he spent in federal custody prior to his release from Maryland's Department of Corrections and return to SCI.  Stroud also agreed to be barred from serving as an officer or director of a public agency for five years, with no credit for time at liberty on parole, and with no right to a parole revocation hearing.  As a condition of his reparole, he was required to serve a balance of the sentence or sentences which he was serving when paroled/reparoled.  He was also required to provide a copy of the No-Merit Letter to the Board, which he did not provide.  On August 15, 2017, the court issued a warrant for Stroud's arrest as a convicted felon (CPV) and ordered him to be retaken and returned forthwith to the actual custody of the Board.  This order also prohibits Stroud from associating with any person who has been convicted of a prior felony with the Board in order to determine whether or not to grant him a reparative or a new sentence of incarceration.  For further information, see Commonwealth v. Pa. Bd. of Probate & Parole, 518 Pa. 491, 544 A.2d 568 (1980).  The Court also granted the parole board's request for a temporary restraining order against Stroud and issued an order suspending him from appearing or practicing before the board as an attorney.
